name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
description: Preserving America's early transportation history, the C&O Canal began as a dream of passage to Western wealth. Operating for nearly 100 years the canal was a lifeline for communities along the Potomac River as coal, lumber, and agricultural products floated down the waterway to market. Today it endures as a pathway for discovering historical, natural, and recreational treasures.
shortDescription: Preserving America's early transportation history, the C&O Canal began as a dream of passage to Western wealth. Operating for nearly 100 years the canal was a lifeline for communities along the Potoma...

operatingHours.description: The towpath is open 365 days a year.

fees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle
fees.description: Pass is for one private, non-commercial vehicle — passenger cars, pickup trucks, RVs and vans — and is valid at the Great Falls area of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal National Historical Park on the Maryland side of the Potomac River and Great Falls Park on the Virginia side of the Potomac River.

fees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle
fees.description: Valid for 7 days. Admits up to 2 private, non-commercial motorcycles with up to 4 total passengers to the Great Falls area of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal National Historical Park on the Maryland side of the Potomac River and at Great Falls Park on the Virginia side of the Potomac River.

fees.title: Entrance - Per Person
fees.description: Pass is for one person 16 years of age or older — entering on foot or by bicycle — and is valid at the Great Falls area of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal National Historical Park on the Maryland side of the Potomac River and at Great Falls Park on the Virginia side of the Potomac River.

fees.title: Entrance - Non-commercial Groups
fees.description:
Includes church groups, college/school groups, scouts, service organizations, military, etc...
Vehicles with passenger capacity of fewer than 16 persons, $20 for the vehicle.
Vehicles with a passenger capacity of 16 or more persons, $10 per person age 16 and over.
Removal of seats from a vehicle does not then qualify for the lower rate. Age and pass exemptions apply.
The total fee charged for an Organized Non-Commercial Group will not exceed the $100 fee per vehicle.

fees.title: Commercial Entrance - Motor Coach
fees.description: The commercial pass is valid for date of purchase plus six days at the Great Falls area of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal National Historical Park on the Maryland side of the Potomac River. Please note that fees are based on vehicle capacity and not actual occupants.

fees.title: Commercial Entrance - Van
fees.description: The commercial pass is valid for date of purchase plus six days at the Great Falls area of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal National Historical Park on the Maryland side of the Potomac River. Please note that fees are based on vehicle capacity and not actual occupants.

fees.title: Commercial Entrance - Mini-bus
fees.description: The commercial pass is valid for date of purchase plus six days at the Great Falls area of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal National Historical Park on the Maryland side of the Potomac River. Please note that fees are based on vehicle capacity and not actual occupants.

fees.title: Commercial Entrance - Sedan
fees.description: The commercial pass is valid for date of purchase plus six days at the Great Falls area of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal National Historical Park on the Maryland side of the Potomac River. Please note that fees are based on vehicle capacity and not actual occupants.

climate.weatherDescription: The Washington, DC, area has a four-season Mid-Atlantic climate. Summertime is warm and humid, while winter can be cold and snowy. Precipitation averages 2-4” monthly, year-round. The climate gradually gets cooler and wetter further west along the canal where the elevation is higher.

images.title: Great Falls of the Potomac
images.altText: The rushing river cascades over the rocks of the Potomac
images.caption: The area of Great Falls is one of the reasons for the C&O Canal needed to be built for boat traffic.

images.title: Bike rider along the towpath
images.altText: A single bike rider on the towpath next to the widewater section of the canal.
images.caption: The towpath offers a serene bike riding experience.

images.title: Lockhouse 16 along the Canal
images.altText: A whitewashed lockhouse sits above a stone lock with wooden crib.
images.caption: Lockhouse 16 sits atop a stone outcropping above the lock.

images.title: Big Slackwater
images.altText: Fog over the Potomac River alongside the Canal towpath.
images.caption: Big Slackwater is a 3 mile stretch where canal boats entered the Potomac River to travel above Dam 4.

images.title: Charles F. Mercer Replica Canal Boat
images.altText: A replica double decker canal boat is being pulled upstream by mules.
images.caption: Mule-drawn canal boat rides are offered at Great Falls Tavern, April through October.
